docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional Democrats rallied today around a bill that would offer prescription drug benefits as part of the Medicare program, in contrast to the approach favored by Republicans, who want to subsidize private insurance to help pay such costs. Several dozen House and Senate Democrats joined in a display of unity at the White House, where they said they had agreed on a proposal to offer coverage of prescription drugs to all Medicare beneficiaries -- 39 million elderly or disabled people.

headline.main: Drug Benefits For Medicare Are Proposed By Democrats

docs.abstract: Congressional Democrats rally around bill that would offer prescription drug benefits as part of Medicare program, in contrast to approach favored by Republicans, who want to subsidize private insurance to help pay such costs; several dozen House and Senate Democrats join in display of unity with Pres Clinton at White House; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Congressional Democrats rallied today around a bill that would offer prescription drug benefits as part of the Medicare program, in contrast to the approach favored by Republicans, who want to subsidize private insurance to help pay such costs.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas proposed a set of tax breaks today to encourage more people to buy long-term-care insurance and to ease the financial burden on people looking after ailing relatives at home. Under Mr. Bush's plan, which anticipates the fast-growing number of older Americans, people of any age who buy insurance for the kind of extended nursing-home stays not covered by other policies or by Medicare could fully deduct the annual premium from their taxes, whether they itemize deductions or not.

headline.main: Bush Pushes Plan for Long-Term Care

docs.abstract: Gov George W Bush proposes set of tax breaks to encourage more people to buy long-term care insurance and to ease financial burden on people looking after ailing relatives at home; long-term care insurance fills gap in what is provided by private and corporate health care policies and Medicare; it covers cost of extended stay in nursing home or assisted-living center for people whose financial resources have not dwindled to point where they qualify for Medicaid; Bush says that to many senior citizens, illness is path to financial ruin; Bush offers his proposal during visit to nursing home in Davenport, Iowa; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas proposed a set of tax breaks today to encourage more people to buy long-term-care insurance and to ease the financial burden on people looking after ailing relatives at home.    Under Mr. Bush's plan, which anticipates...

docs.lead_paragraph: The morning after Gov. George E. Pataki offered Nassau County a $100 million state bailout and help in refinancing its crushing debt load, county officials woke up today to a sobering thought: to get the help they must cut their budget by $260 million -- or more than 10 percent -- over the next four years. In a sense, they were not all that far from where they were last week.

headline.main: Although State Offers Help, Nassau Is Still in Trouble

docs.abstract: Nassau County officials react to Gov George E Pataki offering county $100 million state bailout and help in refinancing its crushing debt load if they agree to cut their budget by $260 million, or more than 10 percent, over next four years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MY husband missed our son's high school graduation due to business travel. None of us has ever forgotten.'' A lot of words were spoken at the World Bank's two-day symposium late last month Stress, the Business Traveler and Corporate Health in Washington. But those two declarative sentences, among the many responses elicited by World Bank managers who surveyed traveling staff members and their spouses, packed real wallop. ''None of us has ever forgotten.''

headline.main: Business Travel; The World Bank gauges the toll travel takes on employees and looks for ways to soften the effect.

docs.abstract: World Bank held two-day symposium last month called Stress, the Business Traveler and Corporate Health in Washington, DC; in last two years, bank has sponsored seminars intended to make employers think more responsibly about effect ever-increasing travel has on employees and on people closest to them (Business Travel column) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Around the besieged provincial legislature building here, the din of banging pots died away, candles flickered in the evening breeze and protesters began singing their hymn: ''Oh Medicare.'' ''Long live our plan, keep it free from greed,'' hundreds of voices sang into the spring night. Referring to the health care plan for all Canadians, they sang, ''Oh Medicare, we stand on guard for thee.''

headline.main: A Crossroads in Canadian Health Care

docs.abstract: Bill offered by Alberta Premier Ralph Klein to allow government reimbursement of private clinics for same surgical procedures performed in government hospitals has spurred demonstrations against perceived threat to Canada's government-run national health plan; dogged loyalty of Albertans to public health system surprises politicians in conservative province; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Striking janitors have reached a tentative agreement with downtown cleaning companies, a month after walking off the job, both sides said today. The members of the union, Service Employees International Union, Local 2028, are to vote on the three-year contract on Tuesday.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Striking Janitors to Vote On Contract in San Diego

docs.abstract: Striking janitors in San Diego, Calif, reach tentative agreement with downtown cleaning companies (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: White House officials and Democrats in Congress say they have become concerned that negotiations on a bill to define patients' rights have stalled. President Clinton has summoned 10 members of Congress to the White House in an effort to galvanize talks on the issue, one of his party's top legislative priorities this year.

headline.main: Clinton Sets Meeting to Spur Progress on Patients' Rights

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton summons 10 members of Congress to White House in effort to galvanize talks on bill to define patients' rights, one of Democratic Party's top legislative issues of year; Democrats do not accuse Republicans of bad faith but say negotiations have become enmeshed in slow, frustrating process that seems to be leading nowhere; negotiations are seen as leadership test for Sen Don Nickles, chairman of House-Senate conference committee; photo (M)
